Edit - Okay, I looked it up...
"Yellow diamonds get their colour through the presence of nitrogen during the formation of the stone. The intensity of the yellow is dependent upon varying amounts of nitrogen. The difference between yellow diamonds and white diamonds is that white diamonds have little to no nitrogen, and therefore do not show colour. Only 1 out of 10,000 carats mined is a yellow diamond".

The radioactivity of an object normally has nothing to do with the object being exposed to radiation. Especially the electron beams he's talking about. A material can be radioactive only if it naturally has an unstable core or by making the core unstable only through neutron radiation who changes the composition of the core, making it unstable. And neutron radioation is something you find in nuclear reactors, particle accelerators etc. So please don't go around saying that exposure to radiation will make you radioactive XD.

The absorption mechanism (around 1:40) is a little oversimplified. They energy is first absorbed by the electrons of the defect and only later dissipated into movement of atoms. The frequency of light is way to high compared to the oscillations of the lattice atoms and thus won't couple directly.

The wedding ring I had originally purchased for my wife had lost a diamond and we decided to go into a local jewelry store and have it replaced. While we were there we saw another ring and asked about it. The person we talked to ended up being one of their goldsmiths and he suggested we could have my wife's ring melted down and made into a smaller version of the ring we had just looked at. With the new ring, it had many more diamonds in it and we asked that maybe some peridot's could be placed in it as we had been married in the month of August. He said that wouldn't be a good idea since the peridot is brittle and over time it would chip or scratch. He took out a green Sharpe and colored every other diamond to show what it would look like if it had green diamonds put in instead of the peridots. We liked the look and now my wife loves her ring that was made from her original wedding ring with green diamonds that to us represent the month we were married.

Of note, electron beams do not cause things to become radioactive. Only neutrons can do this, and that will only happen when things are placed in something like a nuclear reactor system vs a gamma source. So gems treated with cobalt irradiators will not be radioactive at all.
